INTER-FRATERNITY AGREEMENT
EXPIRES NEXT OCTOBER

There has been no definite agreement made by the Inter-fraternity
'Board to govern the "rushings
season' next year. Since the present agreement holds :until next
October, there- will be no rushing
during the summer. It is expected
that the rushing season will commence on the Monday following the
Young Men's Christian Association reteption; and that there will
be an unrestricted season thereafter.
The Trustees and other University officials have taken no definite
action on the fraternity situation at
Homewood. Several of the fraternities, however, have rented houses
near Homewood, and, the others
will do so in the 'fall, unless in the
meantime the authorities make arrangements to have the houses on
the campus as part of the dormitory
system.

Hopkins the Undergraduate.
By Alkert L. Hammond.

I never thought much of undergraduates until I came more into
contact with graduates. To be
sure, even as undergraduate, I put
ourselves ahead of the forces of
outer darkness, so that now of all
special classes—and anathema be
all special classes—the undergraduate becomes the supreme, the capstone of ,an organized civilization.
And this is according to the rights
of the theory. The business of the
college is education. The schools
before are a preparation for college, and, as someone has said, a,
subterfuge for freeing busy parents
from the educating influences of
their juniors. After college, people, as classes, plunge into special
occupations, or into graduate
schools which are vocational. They
make the great admission,-they are
reduced to the ranks, the glory of
the undergraduate passes from
them, and they go to work to enable
their sons to go to college. Education itself a preparation for the
world, "training for efficiency"—
weary, stale, flat, and unprofitable
nonsense, the utter damnableness
of which is yet to be seen. The
world is a preparation for education. Only ultimately is education,
with all other things, preparation,
since "he that would scale the
heights of Heaven must face God."
Education is the appropriation of
an atmosphere, the conquest of a
point of view, the achievement of
liberty. Of course, it is not confined within college walls—often
cannot be found there, class or
campus—and one does not have to
leave his point of view, his atmosphere, his freedom behind when
he gets his diploma; but the college
is the only class explicitly alive with
education as aim, and as such is
supreme as much within the university as beyond. For graduate
work—although in this world of
the impossible, education may persist even through seminaries as
through counting-room and church
—is if anything even more potent
than business in annihilating education. Wherefore, lift up your
heads, 0 ye gates; and be ye lifted
up, ye everlasting doors; and—enter the football hero.
If the college is rightfully to
wrap itself in its toga of glory, it
must be conscious of its senatorial
rank, and bethink itself of its senatorial duties. In the present college athletics alone are pursued as
self-justifying, intellectual interests
are relegated to the possession of
the "nut," and courses to the limbo
of the grind. .The gospel of preparedness, which the undergraduate
consciously at least accepts, dis7
gusts him at least unconsciously
with effort which obviously does
not prepare; leaves him with a very
proper lofty superiority to the poor
grind who buries himself in such
effort under the delusion that it
does prepare, or because the in(Continued on page S, col. 3)

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, jUME 12, 1916.
HAS INITIATION AND BANQUET

NEW REGULATIONS WILL PASS

MANY HOPKINS MEN TO TRAIN

Omicron Delta Kappa Holds First Annual
Initiation Ceremonies - Defandorf,
Stuart, Thompson, Wolfe and
Oppenheimer Admitted.

Only Provision as to Ducking Is Objectionable to Faculty in Proposed Freshman Regulations —Remainder Will
Probably Be in Force Next Fall.

University to Be Represented at Military
Camps —Month at Camp to Be Accepted Instead of Summer Work
for Engineers.

On Tuesday, June 6, at 7 P. M.,
the Omicron Delta Kappa Society
of this University held its first annual initiation at the Hopkins Club.
Five members were admitted into .
the society, and, at the banquet following the initiation ceremonies,
officers,were elected and plans were
considered for the corning year.
The men initiated into the society
were: Edward M. Stuart, '17.
John L. Defandorf, 'i7; J. Trueman Thompson,'17 ; Alexander M.
Wolfe, '18, and Reuben Oppenheimer, '18.
After the initiation ceremonies
had been completed the following
officers were elected for next
year: President, John • C. Knipp,
'17; Vice-President, J. Trueman
Thompson, '17, and SecretaryTreasurer, Alexander M. Wolfe,
'18.
Following the banquet, President; Knipp introduced Dr. John H.
Latane; who, in an informal talk,
presented in brief the idea for
which the society had been 'formed,
and told of the success which had
come to it since its foundation. Dr.
Latane was the speaker at the first
•meeting of the Omicron Delta
Kappa at Washington and Lee.
With the-forming of the Hopkins
circle, his associate membership has
been transferred fiorn Washington
and Lee to' this University.
°thee ',informal talks followed
Dr.. Latane's. Dean Brush spoke
of the need Which the society filled
in University life, and asked for its
co-operation in all matters of Hopkins concern. President Knipp also
spoke of the part which the society
should play in the development of
University spirit-and in the furtherance of all University undertakings.
Present at the initiation ceremonies and the banquet, in addition
to the new members, were Drs.
Murray P. Brush, John C. French,
Ralph V. D. Magoffin and Charles
J. Tilden as faculty members; Dr.
John H. Latane as associate
member, and Myron E. Bagley,
Hiram W. Woodward, Edmund E.
Spieker, John C. Knipp, Vincent J.
Brooks and Paul W. Sutton, as
charter student members.

With the informal approval of
the Faculty Commit ee on Student
Affairs, it is now practically certain
that, with the exception of the first
provision, the new Freshman Regulations proposed by the Junior
Committee and passed unanimously
by the Student Council, will he
adopted in full.
The censored regulation reads as
follows: -The Monday following
the official opening of the University shall be known as 'ducking
day,' on which day all freshmen
shall voluntarily 'duck' or be compelled to 'duck' in the cooling pool
in the south court at Homewood."
The chief objection brought up
by members of the faculty to this
plan is that it would be beyond all
human nature to expect the freshmen to agree to such a proposal
peacefully, and that the class conflicts which would inevitably follow any attempts to compel obediance to the rule would invalidate
the force of the entire regulations.
With this one exception, the concensus of faculty opinion seems to
be strongly in favor of the regulations, and while no official action
has been taken by the Academic
Council, there exists scarcely any
doubt that, when the Class of 1920
conies to Homewood next fall, it
will be forced to obey regulations
more stringent than those of any
preceding year.
The regulations will provide,
first, that all freshmen shall wear
the official freshmen cap while on
University property—the cap to be
half black and half blue; second,
that freshmen shall wear black
socks and neckties until they have
won two athletic contests from the
sophomores; third, that freshmen
shall not walk on the grass at
Homewood nor use the steps from
the upper quadrangle to the south
court; fourth, that freshmen shall
be made to occupy seats in the rooters' section at all games at Homewood Field; fifth, that no freshman shall smoke or wear his hat
in any University building; sixth,
that no freshman shall ride in the
elevators in any University building: and seventh, that no freshman
shall wear a letter or any insignia
of athletic ability won at a preparatory school.

Hopkins men will hay,‘ special
inducements to join the various
military and naval civilian activities
this summer. Nearly fifty men
have already promised to attend
the Plattsburg and Og-lethorpe
training camps, and many others
are contemplating making the battle-ship cruise offered by the Navy
Department.
It has recently been announced
by the heads of the Engineering
School that a month spent at one
of the military or naval training
camps will be accepted in the place
of the summer work which has been
required in previous years. This
work is not the surveying which is
now going on—that still is compulsory. Even the surveying, however, will .be cut short two or three
days for the men who wish to attend the student camps at Plattsburg and Oglethorpe. Professor
Tilden, who has taken an active
part in the military training at Hopkins this spring, is the originator
of both these plans.
The naval training cruise begins
on August 15 and lasts until September 12. The course of training
is to be given on reserve battleships. The qualifications for enrollment which Hopkins men will
have to possess are as follows:
Must be a citizen of the United
States, in good standing and vouched for by at least two reputable
citizens whose standings are known
to the recruiting officer.
Age 19 to 45, inclusive. Minors
must have the consent of parent
or guardian.
Must pass a prescribed physical
examination.
Previous service in the Army,
Navy or Marine Corps, if any,
must have been honorable.
On the cruise a portion of the
day will be given up to the study
of special subjects, which will 13-e
largely optional, so that recruits
who have aptitude for or knowledge of such subjects as navigation, signalling, radio work, steam
or electrical engineering, etc., may
have an opportunity to specialize.
Boat drills will be given 'and landings made, and recruits will be
taught the manual of arms and
military formations. During the
final week of the cruise the ships
will return to- the naval districts
whence they came, and, in addition
to the courses of instruction, recruits will be given a general idea
of their own naval district and its
defensive problems.
At the expiration of the cruise,
each recruit will announce his intention as to whether or not he will
volunteer for service in the Navy
in case of war occurring within the
next four years. He will also be
given a certificate signed by the
commanding officer of the ship,

• Pres. Goodnow Heads Board.

President Frank Johnson Goodnow has been appointed by Governor Harrington to serve as chairman of the State Agricultural
Board. Dr. Goodnow, as chairman
of the Economy and Efficiency
Commission, which recommended
the program of financial and governmental reform for the State followed by the last legislature in its
merging of many State offices, is
in a position to be of signal Service
on this board. The Agricultural
Board likewise constitutes the
Boar 'l of Trustees of the Maryland
Agricultural College.

Prof. F. W. Taussig, whose text
on economics is used in Political
Economy I, will give a course of
lectures on the tariff and high protection this summer at the University of California.
The National Foreign Trade
Council has given $15o to the University of Wisconsin to be offered
in prizes for student essays on the
Merchant Marine. The first prize
is $too, and the second $5o.

BALTIMORE, MD., JUNE 12, 1916.
The Seniors.

II

With the Class of 1916 goes out
the last class to be trained and nurtured under the dingy ceilings of
McCoy Hall; with it ends the long
line of customs and traditions
which must inevitably grow up
about a locality held for 40 years.
Between the seniors of this year
and next there will be the chasm
of an altered student life. Yet
the difference will, must be, only
superficial. Hopkins can never
alter or modify the ideals for which
it has stood since its foundation—
that way lies smugness and mediocrity. The cultural endeavor, the
intellectual contact with the best
there is in the University, culminating in the high dreams and firm
resolves without which a degree
degenerates into a title, for which
all the Hopkins classes of the past
have stood, can neither end nor
vary with a mere change in place.
The seniors do indeed represent the
end of an era, but it is only an era
of physical restriction; between the
aims of the past and the future
there can be no break.
'Eulogies of graduation are commonplace and meaningless. The
class which will graduate tomorrow
will not shake the nation with .the
thunder of its release—it is not
meant to. The men whom it will
send out into the world do not hold
among their ranks the learning of
the ages, nor the intensified and

sifted ability of a carefully labelled
intelleCtual aristocracy. Yet the
seniors whom. Hopkins has produced this year do stand, as Hopkins classes must always stand, for
two all important and all comprehensive things—breadth of appreciation and breadth of purpose.
A Building for Student Activities.

In every university there must
be one definite locality where student interest in student organizations may come to a head. In the
histories of many colleges, such
localities have first been the campus in general, with separate buildings for each organization coming
as a late and luxurious development. The plan recently proposed
to convert the present Carroll
stable at Homewood into a building
to house all student offices and
meeting places steers a middle path
between the two extremes. It seeks
to furnish means f,or each student
interest to follow its own particular line of development with some
modicum of centralization rather
than for each headquarter to flit
promiscuously about the college
green; and it comes at a time when
the condition of growth into which
the University is about to embark
makes the provision of such a building, far from a luxury, a necessity.
That such a building as the one
proposed would tend towards the
development of Hopkins spirit
among undergraduates, there can
hardly be any question. The very
life of the University centers about
its student activities ; the stronger
the development of those activities,
the greater the cohesion and the
unity of aim among the student body
as a whole. Hopkins has no desire
to so violate its ideals and its tradi-,
tions as to become an institution
advertised with its student life in
doub!e headlines and its university
curriculum in footnotes ; nor does
the proposed plan tend to any such
result. It only provides sane and
normal opportunities for that college life which makes an institution
of learning a separate community.
It is seldom in the history of
Hopkins that its alumni have been
called upon as a body to contribute
a sum unobtainable in any other
way; there has not been nor is it
likely that there will ever again be
another building planned and accomplished by contributions from
the entire body of our graduates.
We are not a large university, with
a hundred thousand men hanging
our diploma upon their walls ; in
numbers, we are small. Yet there is
a closeness among our students and
our graduates whichi many another
institution loses because of its very
size ; the future of the student activity building could in no way be
better guaranteed than by entrusting its accomplishment entirely to
the generosity of the men. who have
once felt themselves the need which
we are facing today.

I

The Removal to Homewood.
By President Frank J. Goodnow.

The removal of the Philosophical Department of the University
to the new site at Homewood marks
the beginning of the end of the
movement which started more than
ten years ago to provide this branch
of the University with more commodius and attractive quarters.
We shall, unfortunately, as probably all interested in the University
know, not be able, at present, to
make provision at Homewood for
the laboratory work in chemistry.
The undergraduate lectures in that
subject will be given, it is true, at
the new site; but the undergraduate laboratory, as well as all the
graduate work in chemistry, will be
carried on in the present quarters
of the department.
Much of •the work of the University after the move to Homewood- will therefore be carried on
under conditions which cannot be
regarded as ideal. Many of the
students, both graduate and undergraduate, will undoubtedly be put
to serious inconvenience because of
the separation of the Chemical
Laboratory from the rest of the
work of the Philosophical Department. At the same time it is believed that on the whole less inconvenience will be felt by the student body after the removal than
is experienced now. For it is to
be remembered that most of the
engineering students have, during
the past two years, been obliged to
do part of their work at the old
site and part in the new Engineering Building.
Furthermore, we shall, until we
are able to construct one or more
additional buildings at the new site,
be somewhat crowded in our new
quarters. The Academic Building, which was intended to house
merely the non-scientific departments and the general library, will
for the time being have to care as
well for zoology and botany, part of
the work in psychology and most of
the administrative work of the entire University. Physics will share
with mechanical and electrical engineering one of the engineering
buildings, and geology and civil engineering will both find shelter in
the new Civil Engineering Building.
The move to Homewood will,
therefore, unquestionably present
difficult problems. The solution
reached will undoubtedly in a number of instances not be entirely
satisfactory to all those interested.
The wisest solution possible cannot

be made without the exhibition of a
great deal of patience by those concerned. There is, however, no
reason why, if we all try our best
to accommodate ourselves to the
new conditions, 'we should not be
able to carry on the work of both
graduate and undergraduate departments harmoniously and effectively.
Indeed, there will unquestionably
be many advantages attaching to
the work of the University at
Homewood even under the rather
unfavorable conditions under which
it will be inaugurated the coming
year—advantages which will become more and more apparent
after we have become shaken down
into our surroundings.
We shall, in the first place;have a
sense of'permanence which has
been impossible so long as we knew
that in all probability we should
move in the near future. We shall
come very soon to realize that we
are in what in all probability will
be the permanent home of the
Philosophical Department of the
University. We shall surround
ourselves gradually with those incidentals which give an academic atmosphere, but which are impossible
in a merely temporary home. We
all, I think, have felt the absence of
such an atmosphere at the old site.
Situated as we have been in the
midst of city life, it was difficult,
if not impossible, for us to be subjected to many of those influences
which do so much to give the University man the poise, the outlook,
the proper sense of values, so necessary for the'really educated man.
We shall, in the second place, have
a home of remarkable beauty. The
great natural charm of the Homewood site, with its views, its woods,
its flowers and its shrubbery, and
the artistic buildings, which will
ever increase in their attractiveness
as the architectural plan approaches
realization, cannot fail to exert a
continuous if silent and impalpable
influence of the greatest educational
value on us all—teachers as well as
students. If we are able in the
coming year to carry through our
plan .of building at least one dormitory, we shall not only have
added .to the attractiveness of the
Homewood site, but we shall also
have strengthened greatly its intangible influence. We hope, if
this plan is realized, that the advantages of the Homewood site will
be availed of by the students of the
Medical School. At present about
all that they know of Homewood is
that there is an athletic field there
which only a few of them use.
We hope, however, soon to have in
addition to the field a number of
tennis courts which will be al:railable to all members of th?, Uni-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JUNE 12, 1916.

JOHNS HOPKINS PREPARES TO LEAVE ITS OLD HOME
McCOY HALL TO BE DESERTED

WALTER TO STAY WITH HOPKINS

Monument Street Buildings, Which Have
Housed Hopkins Since 1876, to Be
Put on Sale —Changes to Occur in Student Life.

Announces in Person That He Will Have
New Barber Shop at Homewood.
Location Has Not Yet Been
Decided Upon.

With the closing examination on
June 6 ended the la-it collegiate
year which Johns Hopkins University will evekikpend in McCoy Hall.
When the Viversity opens next
fall, all classes will be held a'
Homewood, all 'student life will
center about the. Hom.n4Tood campus; with the exception of the
Chemical Laboratory, the buildings
which Hopkins has occupied for
forty years will be empty.
This year ends a definite phase
of Hopkins history, a phase in some
respect unique among American
universities. Located in the heart
of a large city, its student meeting
place a darkened basement and its
campus a narrow alley of brick,
for half a century Hopkins has carried on its work and developed
its traditions amid circumstances
which would have disheartened,
many a larger and financially
stronger institution. Yet the very.
things which to the outside world
might be called handicaps have endeared themselves to a long line of
Hopkins men, and parting from the
Monument street site comes with a
distinct pang to the entire University.

Contrary to all forebodings and
in full accord with the University's'
fondest hopes, there will be a barber-shop at Homewood, and, what
is infinitely more important, it wiil
be presided over, as it has been
presided over in the past, by our
own irreplaceable Walter.
It is Walter himself who is the
maker of this announcement. The interview was to have been one of condolences and memories; instead, it
turned on the tonsorial possibilities
of the new -Academic Building attic.
He was not sure, Walter sated
cautiously—the guarantee of his
future residence had not as yet
been made definite enough for him
to go the length of moving the
treasures of the barber-shop from
their old abode; but he had received
assurances, he. acknowledged—in
his own mind even now there was
no doubt—and all that really
troubled him was the best location
for him in the new Homewood
buildings.
The choice ranges from the basement of the Carroll Mansion to the
present corn-crib of the old Carroll
stable. Walter confided, however,
that, at present, the most available site seems to be the aforementioned attic of the Academic
Building. Whatever be his new
location, he stated, every picture
and souvenir of the present shop
will go to Homewood with him.

Next year the Monument street
buildings will be vacant. No plans
have been made for their disposal,
they are merely on sale to the highest bidder. The Geological Building is already partly in the hands
of the Baltimore City College; that
institution may take over the remainder of the structure once that
Hopkins has finally evacuated. The
possibilities for the disposal of
McCoy Hall are numerous and
varied. It may be used as a lecture
hall, it may be rented as a dancing
auditorium, or it may be converted
into a garage. Yet these are only

possibilities; meanwhile, the corridors will remain bleak and deserted,
the bulletin board will present but
a blank stretch of wall, the double
doors of the basement will be firmly
locked, and the elevator will slowly
rot upon its moorings.
At Homewood, all will be new
and efficient. There will be no
trace or reminder of the present
postoffice, with its- easy access into
the cloak-room and its inevitable
9 o'clock crowd surging in front
of the window; instead, in the new
basement, there will be a system
of individual boxes, open at all
times to the holders of the combinations. There will be no more

crawling journeys from first floor
to fourth, with the whole rusty lift
shaking menacingly as each successive foot is gained; at Homewood the elevators will be sure and
fast and shiny. There will be no
more wooden steps worn into hollows on the inside curve by the
footsteps of thousands of Hopkins
men gone by; it will take long generations to wear hollows in the iron
stairs of the new Academic Building.
The campus of the Hopkins of
old will soon be gone forever. The
classes of the future will learn the
lore of university ways beneath
generous trees and on velvet lawns,
not on curb stones and flags, to
the accompaniment of rumbling
wagons and trolley cars. When
Hopkirls men speak of their campus in the future, there will be no
quotation marks about the phrase.
This year's Summer School will
be the last time that classes will
ever be held in McCoy Hall under
Hopkins auspices. Already the _interior has been stripped; hooks and
offices have been transferred to the
new site. In four months, the longdreamt dream of Homewood will
be a reality.

Hopkins the Undergraduate.
(Continued from page 5)

is not a real college among you !"
But speak in deed and accomplishment as did Gilman. Let us have a
real college. Away with all Philistines, whether athlete, grind or
undifferentiated. A real undergraduate body has the unquestionable right and power to get rid of
anyone it does not want, employee,
student, or professor. Overboard
with all Philistines—but don't
imagine I preach any community of
wild romanticists presided over by
Gautier in green trousers and Oscar
Wilde in lemon-colored gloves. The
college is to be the achievement of
liberty from all intellectual shackles
of time, place and convention;
romanticism is a glamour that is
past, and doctrinairism of any sort
is, of course, the straitest of jackets.
Even sincerity must be of the spirit,
not of the letter, explicit doctrine.
"I am always insincere as knowing
there are many moods."
We have had a historic existence
in our few brief years and our
few dingy buildings here at
Howard street and Druid Hill avenue. The University revolutionized
American graduate Study by envisaging an ideal and realizing it.
The college has at least reflected
the truth of their atmosphere, and
is the place of all places for the
achievement of a college ideal. Let
us not write Ichabod over these
doors and retire to a middle class
complacency -at Homewood. The
graduate schools face a crisis of
their own in the preservation of
their heritage. Shall the college be
content with the hope of becoming
"a regular college," and set off on
a long stern chase, by the imitation
of externals and particulars, of institutions whose fruitage is far
from unquestioned, and whose age
and size are a vast advantage in
their own course, though a handicap which we do not have to overcome in the working out of our
own salvation ?

INTER-FRATERNITY AGREEMENT
EXPIRES NEXT OCTOBER

There has been no definite agreement made by the Inter-fraternity
'Board to govern the "rushings
season' next year. Since the present agreement holds :until next
October, there- will be no rushing
during the summer. It is expected
that the rushing season will commence on the Monday following the
Young Men's Christian Association reteption; and that there will
be an unrestricted season thereafter.
The Trustees and other University officials have taken no definite
action on the fraternity situation at
Homewood. Several of the fraternities, however, have rented houses
near Homewood, and, the others
will do so in the 'fall, unless in the
meantime the authorities make arrangements to have the houses on
the campus as part of the dormitory
system.

Hopkins the Undergraduate.
By Alkert L. Hammond.

I never thought much of undergraduates until I came more into
contact with graduates. To be
sure, even as undergraduate, I put
ourselves ahead of the forces of
outer darkness, so that now of all
special classes—and anathema be
all special classes—the undergraduate becomes the supreme, the capstone of ,an organized civilization.
And this is according to the rights
of the theory. The business of the
college is education. The schools
before are a preparation for college, and, as someone has said, a,
subterfuge for freeing busy parents
from the educating influences of
their juniors. After college, people, as classes, plunge into special
occupations, or into graduate
schools which are vocational. They
make the great admission,-they are
reduced to the ranks, the glory of
the undergraduate passes from
them, and they go to work to enable
their sons to go to college. Education itself a preparation for the
world, "training for efficiency"—
weary, stale, flat, and unprofitable
nonsense, the utter damnableness
of which is yet to be seen. The
world is a preparation for education. Only ultimately is education,
with all other things, preparation,
since "he that would scale the
heights of Heaven must face God."
Education is the appropriation of
an atmosphere, the conquest of a
point of view, the achievement of
liberty. Of course, it is not confined within college walls—often
cannot be found there, class or
campus—and one does not have to
leave his point of view, his atmosphere, his freedom behind when
he gets his diploma; but the college
is the only class explicitly alive with
education as aim, and as such is
supreme as much within the university as beyond. For graduate
work—although in this world of
the impossible, education may persist even through seminaries as
through counting-room and church
—is if anything even more potent
than business in annihilating education. Wherefore, lift up your
heads, 0 ye gates; and be ye lifted
up, ye everlasting doors; and—enter the football hero.
If the college is rightfully to
wrap itself in its toga of glory, it
must be conscious of its senatorial
rank, and bethink itself of its senatorial duties. In the present college athletics alone are pursued as
self-justifying, intellectual interests
are relegated to the possession of
the "nut," and courses to the limbo
of the grind. .The gospel of preparedness, which the undergraduate
consciously at least accepts, dis7
gusts him at least unconsciously
with effort which obviously does
not prepare; leaves him with a very
proper lofty superiority to the poor
grind who buries himself in such
effort under the delusion that it
does prepare, or because the in(Continued on page S, col. 3)

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, jUME 12, 1916.
HAS INITIATION AND BANQUET

NEW REGULATIONS WILL PASS

MANY HOPKINS MEN TO TRAIN

Omicron Delta Kappa Holds First Annual
Initiation Ceremonies - Defandorf,
Stuart, Thompson, Wolfe and
Oppenheimer Admitted.

Only Provision as to Ducking Is Objectionable to Faculty in Proposed Freshman Regulations —Remainder Will
Probably Be in Force Next Fall.

University to Be Represented at Military
Camps —Month at Camp to Be Accepted Instead of Summer Work
for Engineers.

On Tuesday, June 6, at 7 P. M.,
the Omicron Delta Kappa Society
of this University held its first annual initiation at the Hopkins Club.
Five members were admitted into .
the society, and, at the banquet following the initiation ceremonies,
officers,were elected and plans were
considered for the corning year.
The men initiated into the society
were: Edward M. Stuart, '17.
John L. Defandorf, 'i7; J. Trueman Thompson,'17 ; Alexander M.
Wolfe, '18, and Reuben Oppenheimer, '18.
After the initiation ceremonies
had been completed the following
officers were elected for next
year: President, John • C. Knipp,
'17; Vice-President, J. Trueman
Thompson, '17, and SecretaryTreasurer, Alexander M. Wolfe,
'18.
Following the banquet, President; Knipp introduced Dr. John H.
Latane; who, in an informal talk,
presented in brief the idea for
which the society had been 'formed,
and told of the success which had
come to it since its foundation. Dr.
Latane was the speaker at the first
•meeting of the Omicron Delta
Kappa at Washington and Lee.
With the-forming of the Hopkins
circle, his associate membership has
been transferred fiorn Washington
and Lee to' this University.
°thee ',informal talks followed
Dr.. Latane's. Dean Brush spoke
of the need Which the society filled
in University life, and asked for its
co-operation in all matters of Hopkins concern. President Knipp also
spoke of the part which the society
should play in the development of
University spirit-and in the furtherance of all University undertakings.
Present at the initiation ceremonies and the banquet, in addition
to the new members, were Drs.
Murray P. Brush, John C. French,
Ralph V. D. Magoffin and Charles
J. Tilden as faculty members; Dr.
John H. Latane as associate
member, and Myron E. Bagley,
Hiram W. Woodward, Edmund E.
Spieker, John C. Knipp, Vincent J.
Brooks and Paul W. Sutton, as

With the informal approval of
the Faculty Commit ee on Student
Affairs, it is now practically certain
that, with the exception of the first
provision, the new Freshman Regulations proposed by the Junior
Committee and passed unanimously
by the Student Council, will he
adopted in full.
The censored regulation reads as
follows: -The Monday following
the official opening of the University shall be known as 'ducking
day,' on which day all freshmen
shall voluntarily 'duck' or be compelled to 'duck' in the cooling pool
in the south court at Homewood."
The chief objection brought up
by members of the faculty to this
plan is that it would be beyond all
human nature to expect the freshmen to agree to such a proposal
peacefully, and that the class conflicts which would inevitably follow any attempts to compel obediance to the rule would invalidate
the force of the entire regulations.
With this one exception, the concensus of faculty opinion seems to
be strongly in favor of the regulations, and while no official action
has been taken by the Academic
Council, there exists scarcely any
doubt that, when the Class of 1920
conies to Homewood next fall, it
will be forced to obey regulations
more stringent than those of any
preceding year.
The regulations will provide,
first, that all freshmen shall wear
the official freshmen cap while on
University property—the cap to be
half black and half blue; second,
that freshmen shall wear black
socks and neckties until they have
won two athletic contests from the
sophomores; third, that freshmen
shall not walk on the grass at
Homewood nor use the steps from
the upper quadrangle to the south
court; fourth, that freshmen shall
be made to occupy seats in the rooters' section at all games at Homewood Field; fifth, that no freshman shall smoke or wear his hat
in any University building; sixth,
that no freshman shall ride in the
elevators in any University building: and seventh, that no freshman
shall wear a letter or any insignia
of athletic ability won at a preparatory school.

Hopkins men will hay,‘ special
inducements to join the various
military and naval civilian activities
this summer. Nearly fifty men
have already promised to attend
the Plattsburg and Og-lethorpe
training camps, and many others
are contemplating making the battle-ship cruise offered by the Navy
Department.
It has recently been announced
by the heads of the Engineering
School that a month spent at one
of the military or naval training
camps will be accepted in the place
of the summer work which has been
required in previous years. This
work is not the surveying which is
now going on—that still is compulsory. Even the surveying, however, will .be cut short two or three
days for the men who wish to attend the student camps at Plattsburg and Oglethorpe. Professor
Tilden, who has taken an active
part in the military training at Hopkins this spring, is the originator
of both these plans.
The naval training cruise begins
on August 15 and lasts until September 12. The course of training
is to be given on reserve battleships. The qualifications for enrollment which Hopkins men will
have to possess are as follows:
Must be a citizen of the United
States, in good standing and vouched for by at least two reputable
citizens whose standings are known
to the recruiting officer.
Age 19 to 45, inclusive. Minors
must have the consent of parent
or guardian.
Must pass a prescribed physical
examination.
Previous service in the Army,
Navy or Marine Corps, if any,
must have been honorable.
On the cruise a portion of the
day will be given up to the study
of special subjects, which will 13-e
largely optional, so that recruits
who have aptitude for or knowledge of such subjects as navigation, signalling, radio work, steam
or electrical engineering, etc., may
have an opportunity to specialize.
Boat drills will be given 'and landings made, and recruits will be
taught the manual of arms and
military formations. During the
final week of the cruise the ships
will return to- the naval districts
whence they came, and, in addition
to the courses of instruction, recruits will be given a general idea
of their own naval district and its
defensive problems.
At the expiration of the cruise,
each recruit will announce his intention as to whether or not he will
volunteer for service in the Navy
in case of war occurring within the
next four years. He will also be
given a certificate signed by the
commanding officer of the ship,

BALTIMORE, MD., JUNE 12, 1916.
The Seniors.

II

With the Class of 1916 goes out
the last class to be trained and nurtured under the dingy ceilings of
McCoy Hall; with it ends the long
line of customs and traditions
which must inevitably grow up
about a locality held for 40 years.
Between the seniors of this year
and next there will be the chasm
of an altered student life. Yet
the difference will, must be, only
superficial. Hopkins can never
alter or modify the ideals for which
it has stood since its foundation—
that way lies smugness and mediocrity. The cultural endeavor, the
intellectual contact with the best
there is in the University, culminating in the high dreams and firm
resolves without which a degree
degenerates into a title, for which
all the Hopkins classes of the past
have stood, can neither end nor
vary with a mere change in place.
The seniors do indeed represent the
end of an era, but it is only an era
of physical restriction; between the
aims of the past and the future
there can be no break.
'Eulogies of graduation are commonplace and meaningless. The
class which will graduate tomorrow
will not shake the nation with .the
thunder of its release—it is not
meant to. The men whom it will
send out into the world do not hold
among their ranks the learning of
the ages, nor the intensified and

sifted ability of a carefully labelled
intelleCtual aristocracy. Yet the
seniors whom. Hopkins has produced this year do stand, as Hopkins classes must always stand, for
two all important and all comprehensive things—breadth of appreciation and breadth of purpose.
A Building for Student Activities.

In every university there must
be one definite locality where student interest in student organizations may come to a head. In the
histories of many colleges, such
localities have first been the campus in general, with separate buildings for each organization coming
as a late and luxurious development. The plan recently proposed
to convert the present Carroll
stable at Homewood into a building
to house all student offices and
meeting places steers a middle path
between the two extremes. It seeks
to furnish means f,or each student
interest to follow its own particular line of development with some
modicum of centralization rather
than for each headquarter to flit
promiscuously about the college
green; and it comes at a time when
the condition of growth into which
the University is about to embark
makes the provision of such a building, far from a luxury, a necessity.
That such a building as the one
proposed would tend towards the
development of Hopkins spirit
among undergraduates, there can
hardly be any question. The very
life of the University centers about
its student activities ; the stronger
the development of those activities,
the greater the cohesion and the
unity of aim among the student body
as a whole. Hopkins has no desire
to so violate its ideals and its tradi-,
tions as to become an institution
advertised with its student life in
doub!e headlines and its university
curriculum in footnotes ; nor does
the proposed plan tend to any such
result. It only provides sane and
normal opportunities for that college life which makes an institution
of learning a separate community.
It is seldom in the history of
Hopkins that its alumni have been
called upon as a body to contribute
a sum unobtainable in any other
way; there has not been nor is it
likely that there will ever again be
another building planned and accomplished by contributions from
the entire body of our graduates.
We are not a large university, with
a hundred thousand men hanging
our diploma upon their walls ; in
numbers, we are small. Yet there is
a closeness among our students and
our graduates whichi many another
institution loses because of its very
size ; the future of the student activity building could in no way be
better guaranteed than by entrusting its accomplishment entirely to
the generosity of the men. who have
once felt themselves the need which
we are facing today.

I

The Removal to Homewood.
By President Frank J. Goodnow.

The removal of the Philosophical Department of the University
to the new site at Homewood marks
the beginning of the end of the
movement which started more than
ten years ago to provide this branch
of the University with more commodius and attractive quarters.
We shall, unfortunately, as probably all interested in the University
know, not be able, at present, to
make provision at Homewood for
the laboratory work in chemistry.
The undergraduate lectures in that
subject will be given, it is true, at
the new site; but the undergraduate laboratory, as well as all the
graduate work in chemistry, will be
carried on in the present quarters
of the department.
Much of •the work of the University after the move to Homewood- will therefore be carried on
under conditions which cannot be
regarded as ideal. Many of the
students, both graduate and undergraduate, will undoubtedly be put
to serious inconvenience because of
the separation of the Chemical
Laboratory from the rest of the
work of the Philosophical Department. At the same time it is believed that on the whole less inconvenience will be felt by the student body after the removal than
is experienced now. For it is to
be remembered that most of the
engineering students have, during
the past two years, been obliged to
do part of their work at the old
site and part in the new Engineering Building.
Furthermore, we shall, until we
are able to construct one or more
additional buildings at the new site,
be somewhat crowded in our new
quarters. The Academic Building, which was intended to house
merely the non-scientific departments and the general library, will
for the time being have to care as
well for zoology and botany, part of
the work in psychology and most of
the administrative work of the entire University. Physics will share
with mechanical and electrical engineering one of the engineering
buildings, and geology and civil engineering will both find shelter in
the new Civil Engineering Building.
The move to Homewood will,
therefore, unquestionably present
difficult problems. The solution
reached will undoubtedly in a number of instances not be entirely
satisfactory to all those interested.
The wisest solution possible cannot

be made without the exhibition of a
great deal of patience by those concerned. There is, however, no
reason why, if we all try our best
to accommodate ourselves to the
new conditions, 'we should not be
able to carry on the work of both
graduate and undergraduate departments harmoniously and effectively.
Indeed, there will unquestionably
be many advantages attaching to
the work of the University at
Homewood even under the rather
unfavorable conditions under which
it will be inaugurated the coming
year—advantages which will become more and more apparent
after we have become shaken down
into our surroundings.
We shall, in the first place;have a
sense of'permanence which has
been impossible so long as we knew
that in all probability we should
move in the near future. We shall
come very soon to realize that we
are in what in all probability will
be the permanent home of the
Philosophical Department of the
University. We shall surround
ourselves gradually with those incidentals which give an academic atmosphere, but which are impossible
in a merely temporary home. We
all, I think, have felt the absence of
such an atmosphere at the old site.
Situated as we have been in the
midst of city life, it was difficult,
if not impossible, for us to be subjected to many of those influences
which do so much to give the University man the poise, the outlook,
the proper sense of values, so necessary for the'really educated man.
We shall, in the second place, have
a home of remarkable beauty. The
great natural charm of the Homewood site, with its views, its woods,
its flowers and its shrubbery, and
the artistic buildings, which will
ever increase in their attractiveness
as the architectural plan approaches
realization, cannot fail to exert a
continuous if silent and impalpable
influence of the greatest educational
value on us all—teachers as well as
students. If we are able in the
coming year to carry through our
plan .of building at least one dormitory, we shall not only have
added .to the attractiveness of the
Homewood site, but we shall also
have strengthened greatly its intangible influence. We hope, if
this plan is realized, that the advantages of the Homewood site will
be availed of by the students of the
Medical School. At present about
all that they know of Homewood is
that there is an athletic field there
which only a few of them use.
We hope, however, soon to have in
addition to the field a number of
tennis courts which will be al:railable to all members of th?, Uni-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JUNE 12, 1916.

JOHNS HOPKINS PREPARES TO LEAVE ITS OLD HOME
McCOY HALL TO BE DESERTED

WALTER TO STAY WITH HOPKINS

Monument Street Buildings, Which Have
Housed Hopkins Since 1876, to Be
Put on Sale —Changes to Occur in Student Life.

Announces in Person That He Will Have
New Barber Shop at Homewood.
Location Has Not Yet Been
Decided Upon.

With the closing examination on
June 6 ended the la-it collegiate
year which Johns Hopkins University will evekikpend in McCoy Hall.
When the Viversity opens next
fall, all classes will be held a'
Homewood, all 'student life will
center about the. Hom.n4Tood campus; with the exception of the
Chemical Laboratory, the buildings
which Hopkins has occupied for
forty years will be empty.
This year ends a definite phase
of Hopkins history, a phase in some
respect unique among American
universities. Located in the heart
of a large city, its student meeting
place a darkened basement and its
campus a narrow alley of brick,
for half a century Hopkins has carried on its work and developed
its traditions amid circumstances
which would have disheartened,
many a larger and financially
stronger institution. Yet the very.
things which to the outside world
might be called handicaps have endeared themselves to a long line of
Hopkins men, and parting from the
Monument street site comes with a
distinct pang to the entire University.

Contrary to all forebodings and
in full accord with the University's'
fondest hopes, there will be a barber-shop at Homewood, and, what
is infinitely more important, it wiil
be presided over, as it has been
presided over in the past, by our
own irreplaceable Walter.
It is Walter himself who is the
maker of this announcement. The interview was to have been one of condolences and memories; instead, it
turned on the tonsorial possibilities
of the new -Academic Building attic.
He was not sure, Walter sated
cautiously—the guarantee of his
future residence had not as yet
been made definite enough for him
to go the length of moving the
treasures of the barber-shop from
their old abode; but he had received
assurances, he. acknowledged—in
his own mind even now there was
no doubt—and all that really
troubled him was the best location
for him in the new Homewood
buildings.
The choice ranges from the basement of the Carroll Mansion to the
present corn-crib of the old Carroll
stable. Walter confided, however,
that, at present, the most available site seems to be the aforementioned attic of the Academic
Building. Whatever be his new
location, he stated, every picture
and souvenir of the present shop
will go to Homewood with him.

Next year the Monument street
buildings will be vacant. No plans
have been made for their disposal,
they are merely on sale to the highest bidder. The Geological Building is already partly in the hands
of the Baltimore City College; that
institution may take over the remainder of the structure once that
Hopkins has finally evacuated. The
possibilities for the disposal of
McCoy Hall are numerous and
varied. It may be used as a lecture
hall, it may be rented as a dancing
auditorium, or it may be converted
into a garage. Yet these are only

possibilities; meanwhile, the corridors will remain bleak and deserted,
the bulletin board will present but
a blank stretch of wall, the double
doors of the basement will be firmly
locked, and the elevator will slowly
rot upon its moorings.
At Homewood, all will be new
and efficient. There will be no
trace or reminder of the present
postoffice, with its- easy access into
the cloak-room and its inevitable
9 o'clock crowd surging in front
of the window; instead, in the new
basement, there will be a system
of individual boxes, open at all
times to the holders of the combinations. There will be no more

crawling journeys from first floor
to fourth, with the whole rusty lift
shaking menacingly as each successive foot is gained; at Homewood the elevators will be sure and
fast and shiny. There will be no
more wooden steps worn into hollows on the inside curve by the
footsteps of thousands of Hopkins
men gone by; it will take long generations to wear hollows in the iron
stairs of the new Academic Building.
The campus of the Hopkins of
old will soon be gone forever. The
classes of the future will learn the
lore of university ways beneath
generous trees and on velvet lawns,
not on curb stones and flags, to
the accompaniment of rumbling
wagons and trolley cars. When
Hopkirls men speak of their campus in the future, there will be no
quotation marks about the phrase.
This year's Summer School will
be the last time that classes will
ever be held in McCoy Hall under
Hopkins auspices. Already the _interior has been stripped; hooks and
offices have been transferred to the
new site. In four months, the longdreamt dream of Homewood will
be a reality.

Hopkins the Undergraduate.
(Continued from page 5)

is not a real college among you !"
But speak in deed and accomplishment as did Gilman. Let us have a
real college. Away with all Philistines, whether athlete, grind or
undifferentiated. A real undergraduate body has the unquestionable right and power to get rid of
anyone it does not want, employee,
student, or professor. Overboard
with all Philistines—but don't
imagine I preach any community of
wild romanticists presided over by
Gautier in green trousers and Oscar
Wilde in lemon-colored gloves. The
college is to be the achievement of
liberty from all intellectual shackles
of time, place and convention;
romanticism is a glamour that is
past, and doctrinairism of any sort
is, of course, the straitest of jackets.
Even sincerity must be of the spirit,
not of the letter, explicit doctrine.
"I am always insincere as knowing
there are many moods."
We have had a historic existence
in our few brief years and our
few dingy buildings here at
Howard street and Druid Hill avenue. The University revolutionized
American graduate Study by envisaging an ideal and realizing it.
The college has at least reflected
the truth of their atmosphere, and
is the place of all places for the
achievement of a college ideal. Let
us not write Ichabod over these
doors and retire to a middle class
complacency -at Homewood. The
graduate schools face a crisis of
their own in the preservation of
their heritage. Shall the college be
content with the hope of becoming
"a regular college," and set off on
a long stern chase, by the imitation
of externals and particulars, of institutions whose fruitage is far
from unquestioned, and whose age
and size are a vast advantage in
their own course, though a handicap which we do not have to overcome in the working out of our
own salvation ?
